title: 107_hr1098
content: The "Maritime Policy Improvement Act of 2001" includes provisions such as the naming of vessels, expansion of the American Merchant Marine Memorial Wall of Honor, discharge of agricultural cargo residue, recording and discharging maritime liens, and various certificates of documentation for vessels. The Congress recognizes the significant contributions of the United States Merchant Marine in various wars, including serving as the Nation's first navy, keeping the lifeline of freedom open during World War II, and facing dangers from enemies. Over 250,000 men and women served in the Merchant Marine during World War II. During World War II, the United States Merchant Marine faced dangers from submarines, mines, armed raiders, destroyers, aircraft, and kamikaze pilots. Over 6,830 members were killed at sea, 11,000 were wounded, and 604 were taken prisoner. 1 in 32 members died in the line of duty, the highest percentage among all U.S. armed services. The Merchant Marine continues to serve the U.S. and uphold the ideals of its former members. The Secretary of Transportation may grant funds for the American Merchant Marine Veterans Memorial. The American Merchant Marine Veterans Memorial Committee, Inc. is granted funds to add to the Memorial Wall of Honor in Los Angeles. The Federal government will cover 50% of the costs, and $500,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002. SEC. 5. DISCHARGE OF AGRICULTURAL CARGO RESIDUE. The discharge of agricultural cargo residue from a vessel shall be governed by the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships. SEC. 6. RECORDING AND DISCHARGING MARITIME LIENS. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code is amended to allow for the recording and discharging of liens on documented vessels. The Secretary must record a notice complying with the section if a declaration is filed with the notice stating the information is true and correct. The declaration must be sent to the vessel owner, individuals with recorded liens on the vessel, and mortgagees with undischarged mortgages. A non-individual filer must have the declaration signed by an authorized official. Upon full discharge of the debt, a certificate of discharge must be provided to the Secretary for recording. District courts have jurisdiction over actions to declare a vessel lien-free. District courts have jurisdiction over civil actions to declare a vessel lien-free, regardless of the amount in controversy or parties' citizenship. Venue is determined by where the vessel is located, claimant resides, or where the lien is recorded. A notice of claim of lien expires after 3 years. This section does not affect maritime lien laws or defenses like laches. The table of sections in chapter 313 of title 46, United States Code, is amended by removing the item relating to section 31343 and replacing it with a new entry. Section 31343 of title 46, United States Code is amended to include notice requirements for liens on vessels. The Secretary cannot refuse to approve surrender of documentation for a vessel based solely on a recorded lien claim. Additionally, a technical correction is made to the Shipping Act, 1916. The effective date for the section is July 1, 2002, with exceptions outlined in specific sections of the Merchant Marine Act and title 46. SEC. 7. Tonnage measurement for R/V DAVIDSON as a small passenger vessel under title 46, United States Code. Applies when vessel complies with section 3301(8). SEC. 8. Miscellaneous certificates of documentation. The Secretary of Transportation can issue certificates of documentation for vessels like LOOKING GLASS, YANKEE, LUCKY DOG, ENTERPRIZE, M/V SANDPIPER, FRITHA, PUFFIN, VICTORY OF BURNHAM, R'ADVENTURE II, ANTJA, and SKIMMER for employment in the coastwise trade. The vessels listed include SKIMMER, TOKEENA, DOUBLE EAGLE2, ENCOUNTER, AJ, BARGE 10, NOT A SHOT, PRIDE OF MANY, AMAZING GRACE, and SHEWHO, each with their respective official or registration numbers. SEC. 9. EXEMPTION FOR VICTORY SHIPS. Amends Section 3302(l)(1) of title 46, United States Code to exempt SS Red Oak Victory and SS American Victory. SEC. 10. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR 3 BARGES. SEC. 10. CERTIFICATE OF DOCUMENTATION FOR 3 BARGES. The Secretary of Transportation may issue a certificate of documentation for employment in the coastwise trade for three vessels: the former Navy deck barge JIM, the former railroad car barge HUGH, and the former railroad car barge TOMMY. These vessels can only be used as floating platforms for launching fireworks. SEC. 11. The Secretary of Transportation will issue a certificate of documentation for the vessel EAGLE for coastwise trade if owned or chartered by a State entity, operated for specific purposes, and clearly identified. SEC. 12. Waiver for vessels in New World Challenge Race. SEC. 12. WAIVER FOR VESSELS IN NEW WORLD CHALLENGE RACE. Beginning April 1, 2002, 10 sailboats in the race can transport guests without payment until 60 days after the race ends or December 31, 2003. SEC. 13. VESSEL ASPHALT COMMANDER can be transferred to a foreign registry or sold to a non-US citizen.
